content: Both Jean-Jacques Rousseau and John Locke believed in the idea of a social contract, where individuals give up some of their individual rights to a government in exchange for protection and security. Both philosophers also believed in the right to revolt against a government that fails to uphold its end of the contract and the idea of the government being based on the consent of the governed. However, there are also some differences in their beliefs. For example, Locke believed that the primary purpose of government is to protect the natural rights of life, liberty, and property, while Rousseau believed that the primary purpose of government is to ensure the general will and the common good of the community. Additionally, Locke believed that individuals have a right to private property, while Rousseau believed that private property creates inequalities and is therefore incompatible with true freedom.
